body: committed manually
committed manually
Awaiting build results: https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Phoenix/job/Phoenix-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/job/PR-1949/

Thanks @virajjasani .
Disabling the node is a much better solution than excluding it in the CI script, as those exclusions tend to never get removed and accumulate.

@palashc Another test I want you to write is where there are delete markers in the beginning of the table and then you run a query like this `SELECT * FROM <TABLE> LIMIT 1`. It should skip the delete markers till it finds the first valid row.  You could run this query in a loop where in every iteration you could delete more rows which have to be skipped in the subsequent SELECT query.

1. Update the description on Javadocs and PR/Jira to specify Salt bucket case
2. Pass null non-pk column set and if it is not null, add values from KeyValueColumnExpression
3. Loggers with view name and more details if required e.g. for sibling views, if the columns don't match, log the column set for view and sibling view, and also sibling view name
4. Tests with comments on what criteria is covered
We are really close now, thank you for working on this @jinggou!
This PR drastically reduces the number of times a thread sleeps (more than 6x) and visibly reduces total upsert time in ConcurrentMutationsExtendedIT#testConcurrentUpserts().

> Could we introduce an API which always returns a byte array and we simply iterate over the array. That should work regardless whether there is one separator byte or multiple and reduce the amount of code duplication.

This is done with https://github.com/apache/phoenix/pull/1937/commits/c146bfe783374b7d03a968cf5fab8476e685ab30
https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-40152

This is a transitive dependency from hadoop, it is most likely not needed for phoenix. Notice that any product that is using `phoenix-client-embedded` to use Phoenix internally, is flagged with this CVEs

@lhofhansl @JamesRTaylor @palashc Can you please take a look? This is used in Trino phoenix connector. Then it makes entire Trino flagged with his CVE.

CC: @wendigo @kgniew
Thank you. I have created the jira ticket, see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PHOENIX-7393
Has anyone looked at what Hadoop uses this for ?

Looking at https://github.com/apache/hadoop/pull/5087 this seems to have the potential to break Phoenix in rare cases.

While I'm not wild about managing versions for transitive dependencies, in this case I would prefer dependencymanaging the woodstock version instead.

Yeah this has been problematic dependency. @stoty do you know if any/all of our Jackson usages need woodstox?

Build results: https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Phoenix/job/Phoenix-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/job/PR-1957/
@kokosing btw did you also check dependency:tree output and saw woodstox no longer present from any other upstream?

We are certainly not referring the classes directly, and based on the test results it is not needed for any of our test cases either.
I am not familiar with Jackson internals, and when exactly Woodstox is needed.

Reading the Hadoop ticket, it seems that Woodstock is only necessary if hbase-site.xml contains a DTD definition i.e. a <!DOCTYPE... > header.

I think it would wiser not risk breaking Phoenix in case someone has decided to a DTD header to their config files.

> btw did you also check dependency:tree output and saw woodstox no longer present from any other upstream

Yes. I have checked that. After this change there is no more `woodstox` in phoenix build.

> Reading the Hadoop ticket, it seems that Woodstock is only necessary if hbase-site.xml contains a DTD definition i.e. a <!DOCTYPE... > header.

Can we have an unit test to expose that behavior? That way it would be easier to see what it can be done to make sure such use case is still supported.

If we keep Woodstock and dependency manage it to a non-vulnerable version then we can be sure that we won't break anything, and the scanners will be happy.
We already do this for a few components.

Sounds good @stoty, it does not break any compatibility.
@kokosing since you have already made nice progress, could you please also include the dependency on pom directly? or you want someone else to do that? The tests are not impacted so we are good anyway but would be great to include CVE fixed version directly in Phoenix pom.
Yes. I am happy to do it. I will update this PR within few days.

Before we have following woodstox-core usage:
```
kokosing@m2:~/src/apache/phoenix$ mvn dependency:tree -o | grep woodstox | cut -d + -f 2 | sort -u
- com.fasterxml.woodstox:woodstox-core:jar:5.3.0:compile
- com.fasterxml.woodstox:woodstox-core:jar:5.3.0:provided
- com.fasterxml.woodstox:woodstox-core:jar:5.3.0:test
- org.codehaus.woodstox:stax2-api:jar:4.2.1:compile
- org.codehaus.woodstox:stax2-api:jar:4.2.1:provided
- org.codehaus.woodstox:stax2-api:jar:4.2.1:test
```

5.3.0 is flagged with 5 CVEs, see https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.fasterxml.woodstox/woodstox-core/5.3.0, and 5.4.0 is without CVEs, see https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.fasterxml.woodstox/woodstox-core/5.4.0

After a change:
```
kokosing@m2:~/src/apache/phoenix$ mvn dependency:tree -o | grep woodstox | cut -d + -f 2 | sort -u
- com.fasterxml.woodstox:woodstox-core:jar:5.4.0:compile
- com.fasterxml.woodstox:woodstox-core:jar:5.4.0:provided
- com.fasterxml.woodstox:woodstox-core:jar:5.4.0:test
- org.codehaus.woodstox:stax2-api:jar:4.2.1:compile
- org.codehaus.woodstox:stax2-api:jar:4.2.1:provided
- org.codehaus.woodstox:stax2-api:jar:4.2.1:test
```

> Yes. I am happy to do it. I will update this PR within few days.

Actually, it took me shorter :)
The challenge with the current approach is that someone would need to update this whenever the hadoop is updated. I hope it is not going to downgrade the transitive dependency in future.

+1, thank you @kokosing!

@stoty anything from your side?
Previous build has expired, triggered new build: https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Phoenix/job/Phoenix-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/job/PR-1941/

> The challenge with the current approach is that someone would need to update this whenever the hadoop is updated. I hope it is not going to downgrade the transitive dependency in future.

You are right, this is an anti-pattern.
However, as long as we ship uberjars, we have limited options.

> @stoty anything from your side?

Please update the jira descirption to match the commit message.

At some point we should group the transitive-only version overrides into a single section, but that's outside the scope of this ticket.
Thanks Istvan for the reviews

> Please update the jira descirption to match the commit message.

Done
Fixed
Is there anything else I am required to do to push it forward? Are tests failure related?
No, our tests are flakey.
Thank you.
@ujjawal4046 several test failures on the latest build seem relevant? https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Phoenix/job/Phoenix-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/job/PR-1941/3/testReport/

e.g.
```
java.lang.Exception: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.apache.hadoop.mapred.LocalJobRunner$Job.runTasks(LocalJobRunner.java:492) ~[hadoop-mapreduce-client-common-3.2.4.jar:?]
	at org.apache.hadoop.mapred.LocalJobRunner$Job.run(LocalJobRunner.java:552) ~[hadoop-mapreduce-client-common-3.2.4.jar:?]
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException

	at org.apache.phoenix.iterate.ScanningResultIterator.next(ScanningResultIterator.java:204) ~[phoenix-core-client-5.3.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:5.3.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at org.apache.phoenix.iterate.TableSnapshotResultIterator.next(TableSnapshotResultIterator.java:179) ~[phoenix-core-server-5.3.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:5.3.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at org.apache.phoenix.iterate.LookAheadResultIterator$1.advance(LookAheadResultIterator.java:55) ~[phoenix-core-client-5.3.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:5.3.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at org.apache.phoenix.iterate.LookAheadResultIterator.next(LookAheadResultIterator.java:75) ~[phoenix-core-client-5.3.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:5.3.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at org.apache.phoenix.jdbc.PhoenixResultSet.next(PhoenixResultSet.java:884) ~[phoenix-core-client-5.3.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:?]
	at org.apache.phoenix.mapreduce.PhoenixRecordReader.nextKeyValue(PhoenixRecordReader.java:185) ~[phoenix-core-server-5.3.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:5.3.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at org.apache.hadoop.mapred.MapTask$NewTrackingRecordReader.nextKeyValue(MapTask.java:569) ~[hadoop-mapreduce-client-core-3.2.4.jar:?]
```

Are there any plans about the release?
Yes, 5.2.1 release planning related thread is just going on over dev@phoenix mailing list. I just mentioned that we should now move forward for 5.2.1 release after merging the PR.
@kokosing any other CVE that is coming from Hadoop and you think we should resolve it now? It would be great to get them in too if Trino is getting impacted.
Let me check that. Will get back on that.

@virajjasani I have reverted the change for TableSnapshotResultIterator which was causing the test failure due to same optimization of closing early being applied by ScanningResultIterator (which is used outside of MR based snapshot jobs) as well. Fixing it across both iterators isn't feasible without more extensive refactor so parking that. 

Disabling mslab should be sufficient to fix the snapshot issue.

@kgniew did a scan and returned with the following information:

With regards to the phoenix connector there are several CVEs related to
 - `jackson-databind` package located here phoenix5/phoenix-client-embedded-hbase-2.5.0-5.2.0.jar  current package version is 2.4.0  and it should be updated to 2.12.7.1
 - `snappy-java` package located here phoenix5/phoenix-client- embedded-hbase-2.5.0- 5.2.0.jar  current package version is 1.0.5  and it should be updated to 1.1.10.4
 - `protobuf-java`  package located here phoenix5/phoenix-client- embedded-hbase-2.5.0- 5.2.0.jar  current package version is 2.5.0  and it should be updated to 3.16.3
 - `avro` package located here phoenix5/phoenix-client- embedded-hbase-2.5.0- 5.2.0.jar  current package version is 1.7.7  and it should be updated to 1.11.3
 - `json-smart`   package located here phoenix5/phoenix-client- embedded-hbase-2.5.0- 5.2.0.jar  current package version is 1.3.2  and it should be updated to 2.4.9
 - `jettision`   package located here phoenix5/phoenix-client- embedded-hbase-2.5.0- 5.2.0.jar  current package version is 1.1  and it should be updated to 1.5.4
 - `netty`  is also problematic however grype does not provide a fixed version for critical  CVE-2019-20444

I verified this with recent master nad `mvn depedency:tree` and I see:
 - `com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-databind:jar:2.14.1:compile` ✅ 
 - `org.xerial.snappy:snappy-java:jar:1.1.10.4:compile` ✅ 
 - I see no `protobuf-java` anymore ✅ 
 - `org.apache.avro:avro:jar:1.7.7:compile` 👎 
 - `net.minidev:json-smart:jar:2.5.0:runtime` ✅ 
 - `org.codehaus.jettison:jettison:jar:1.1:compile` 👎 
 
 So only `avro` and `jettison` can be improved now.

`avro` is a transitive dependency from `hadoop`. @virajjasani and @stoty do you think it is ok to exclude it? Does Phoenix client need `avro`?

And the same story with `jettison`
FYI @stoty @virajjasani
See a follow up https://github.com/apache/phoenix/pull/1970

Thanks @ujjawal4046
Triggered another build since previous one had env issues https://ci-hadoop.apache.org/job/Phoenix/job/Phoenix-PreCommit-GitHub-PR/job/PR-1941/6/

You fixed the PR description, not the patch description.

It should be 
"PHOENIX-7387 SnapshotScanner's next method is ignoring the boolean value from hbase's nextRaw method"
Fix the description in git, and force-push the change

> Fix the description in git, and force-push the change

Done

I have opened a [DISCUSS] thread on dev@p.a.o. on how to handle transitive dependecy CVEs.
Please join the discussion.
Do we know if CVEs of both of these dependencies have been resolved with some recently released version of Hadoop?
Need to run some tests to see if the minicluster binaries can handle the newer Hadoop (especially for 2.5.0 and 2.4)

2.4 tests fail with Hadoop 3.3 because of the known minicluster incompatibilities, but mixing Hadoop 3.2 and 3.3 does not cause any test failures.

2.4 is EOL anyway.
Do we need to run all tests for 2.5 and 2.6 profiles? or let precommit builds run it?
@tkhurana, thank you very much for reviewing, already fixed the problem.

@jinggou we also need client side metrics. For instance, we already have `CLIENT_METADATA_CACHE_HIT_COUNTER` and `CLIENT_METADATA_CACHE_MISS_COUNTER`. Now we can add remaining i.e. cache size used (estimated), eviction/removal and cache add metrics. Let's see how much we can add there, if it becomes too much work, we can do it on separate follow-up Jira also.

I have run the test for 2.5 manually, and did not see more than the usual failures @virajjasani .
2.6 is tested by the precommit job.
I did not realize I missed the JIRA ID from the commit message, thanks for catching that.
merged manually.
merged manually
@virajjasani Does this change look good? If yes, we can get it in.

+1 for the core changes. Let's fix some of these checkstyle warnings?

Could you also create backport PR against 5.2 branch? This is really nice change to get included with upcoming 5.2.1 release.
Thank you @jinggou!

Thanks.

In the future, please do not put a colon after the JIRA ID, that's not the convention Phoenix uses.
merged manually.

@kadirozde @virajjasani @tkhurana @jpisaac The PR is ready for review. Please review. 

I plan to follow-up with a PR to avoid doing region level scan when major compacting empty CF of a multi-CF table. I have thought of an approach but need to do its feasibility analysis and get it more concrete so, maybe first we can merge this PR and then next I can follow-up with optimization. Thanks
Can you add tests for both varbinary and varbinary encoded to WhereCompilerTest# testWhereInclusion and PartialIndexIT?

> Can you add tests for both varbinary and varbinary encoded to WhereCompilerTest# testWhereInclusion and PartialIndexIT?

Thanks @kadirozde! Added the tests in the latest revision, and addressed previous review comments.
@haridsv i am about to merge the PR but just realized the PR has merge conflict, that most likely came from today's changes.
Yes, looks like there is a new binary type added to the condition, I will resolve the conflict.
@haridsv It would have been better if you only had salt bucket fix in this PR and not CDC related changes.

> @kadirozde @virajjasani @tkhurana @jpisaac The PR is ready for review. Please review.
> 
> I plan to follow-up with a PR to avoid doing region level scan when major compacting empty CF of a multi-CF table. I have thought of an approach but need to do its feasibility analysis and get it more concrete so, maybe first we can merge this PR and then next I can follow-up with optimization. Thanks

Sounds good.
@kadirozde I have addressed the comment. UTs/ITs which are failing are flappers. Are we good to merge the PR and can you please help with merging it. Thanks

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

As there was no activity here, I fixed the remaining issues in #1992

Saw an import issue in code change. Went ahead and raised https://github.com/apache/phoenix/pull/1995/ as fixing manually is too cumbersome
This code can be reviewed, just that not ready for merge. Need to add JIRA title and also decide whether should go as one commit or multi commit.

Done, I also renamed jira and commit message to match the PR title.
Thank you!

There is minimal functionality that we use here.

Wouldn't it be better to just get rid of this dependency ?

There was already a DISCUSS thread on this back in Januray 2023, but nothing happened.

I think that this is visible and high impact enough to warrant another [DISCUSS] thread.

I think we should do this, BTW.
